bioghist.p: Bernard Berenson (1865-1959) was a renowned art historian and the author of several books, including The Drawings of the Florentine Painters. During his lifetime he was regarded as the world's leading authority on Renaissance art. He worked closely with prominent collectors and a number of art dealers in recommending and authenticating works for purchase. His wife, Mary (Smith) Berenson (1864-1945), was also a noted art historian. They willed their estate in Italy, Villa I Tatti, to Harvard University, which uses it as the home for its Center for Italian Renaissance Studies.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of letters, telegrams and postcards from Bernard and Mary Berenson to art collector Carl Hamilton, written between 1919 and 1935. Some of the letters are preserved as photostats. The collection also includes a typescript of an article entitled "Two Twelfth Century Paintings from Constantinople" by Bernard Berenson.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
